To purchaſe bayle for keeping of the child.
So there is one impediment diſpatcht;
Yet I forget the aid • promis'd to
The Draper in his ſuit unto Eliſa,
Who with his painted mole by this is acting
Her ſervant Friendly, whom I ſaid was •• avail'd.
In which diſguiſe he thinks to win her too▪
But 〈◊〉 muſt now deprive the Black a more
Of all this much, in ſeeing of his ſhape
Uſu p' • ; while he ſtands mu • e to hear another
Courting his deareſt M ſtreſs in his name.
But why do I thus talk away the day,
When I ſhould do • leſt time be vainly ſpent,
To redreſſe ills which care might once prevent.

div.stage: Enter Crab, Lydia, Cunnimonger, Goodwis, and Hog.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Come Lydia, now the time draws nigh, when we
With worthies male and female ſhall enrich
The needy world; this morn I ſent unto
A cunning man to learn the fitteſt time
For to engender W •• s in, he replyes,
This night 'twixt twelve and one, do not omit
Thy nuptial duties, the ſtarres counſel it;
If that thou wilt beget a wit tranſcendent,
This night is Hermes lord of the Aſcendent;
Well ſoon I mean for to invite the wits,
Or as thou call'ſt them Frank, Deipnoſophiſts,
Unto my bridal ſupper; where I will
Have nothing but braines diverſly cook't
Of birds, beaſts, fiſhes, tith-pigs, and woodcocks;
Our drink ſhall be brisk c •• iet, for to refine
The Infant's ſparkling • ngenie! but now
Where ſhall we finde a cook of w ••• that has
Not had his education in the kitchin,
Whoſe brain's not overeaſt, with miſtie clouds
Ariſing from the ſteam of groſſer meats.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I'lt be your cook Sir, and though I do ſay't,
I have as good a wit of a groſſe body,
As any woman ever need to boaſt of.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Never take care for chooſing of your cook.
The very dreſſing of the braines will make him w ••• i • .

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: Take you no thought for cook, or cheer, leave theſe
To mine and my old Maſter's care; you now
Muſt feaſt upon your ſweet delicious wife,
• he will be meat and med'cine to you, for her ſight
Alone, the ſhaking ague will affright;
And ſoon at night, if you do not awry go,

She'le eaſe you ſuddenly of th •
• entigo,
Yea before Galen, ſhe will cure the feaver
With her down belly, and her thighes of bever.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: How 〈◊〉 bever doſt thou call them: I am ſure
That they were Felt laſt night; but do you hear▪
Do not you call my Lydis my wife,
It is a name, the countrey people uſe.
No • ſhall ſhe call me husband, therefore Frank,
P • ethee deviſe ſome fine Poetick names,
To dart at one another before ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: What do you think, if you were call'd the Seal.
And ſhe your wax? on whom in every kiſſe
You thus may ſeal the Image of your love. kiſ. her

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.l: Pray heaven I may wax worthy of his love
But truſt me Sir, you do me injurie,
To think his love hath made ſo ſlight impreſſion
Within my breaſt, that it may be defac'r,
Like to a fading image made in wax.

sp.speaker: Goodw.
sp.l: How think you Ladie then, if you were called
His Cynoſure, the ſay'ers ſtarres by which
They finde their way thorough the pathleſs ſeas;
By this they frame their courſe, you Sir muſt be
The Pilot, which does ſteer by her bleſt light
Alone, unto • he haven of your bliſſe:
Or if you will be an Aſtronomer,
In every kiſs thus you may take her height.

sp.speaker: Crab
sp.p: Me thinks this Cynoſure's a pretty name, I pret •• ce tell me what it ſignifies.

sp.speaker: Goodw.
sp.p: It ſignifies properly the dogs taile.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; 'tis the beſt jeſt was ever heard or read of.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: 'Tis a good jeſt indeed can raiſe ſuch mirth;
But my wit's hood winkt, for I cannot finde it:
I pray Sir tell us where the jeſt does lye.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Where it doesly? is it not evident,
That thou didſt kiſs the dog's tail. I ſhall ne • e
Love her again 'till thou haſt chang'd her name.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: You lik't this well untill you underſtood it;
That you may learn from hence how happy 'tis
Sometimes for to be ignorant; what then
If ſhe were call'd your Touchſtone you her ſtraw,
For as •• e Touchſtone doth examine metals,
So will ſhe prove what metal you are made of;
And as the ſtraw doth to the Touchſtone skip,
Thus muſt you cling in every kiſſe you give her:
B • t a •• ve all the name of Lydia move me,
'Cauſe Lapis Lydius ſignifies a Touchſtone.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: I like your reaſons well, but not ſo well
Your often kiſſing, therefore hence, forbear.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Touchſtones the of • ner rub'd, do draw the better.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Fairly put off, well, ſo it is decreed;
A Parliament of wits could not deviſe
More fitting names confirm'd with greater reaſons.

sp.speaker: Sings.
sp.l: To day the Prieſt ſhall make't a law,
That I ſhall be thy onely ſtraw,
The virtue of whoſe Kiſs ſhall draw,
Beſides my ſelf no other ſtraw.

sp.speaker: Lyd. Sings
sp.l: The Touchſtone's black and ſo am I▪
The Touchſtone's hard, and ſo not I;
The Touchſtone doth the metal try,
And as the Touchſtone ſo will I.

sp.speaker: Hog Sings.
sp.l: As ſoon in ſtraw is kindled fire,
So you in flamed with deſire;
Yellow's the ſtraw, yet I ſuppoſe,
That you will ne're wear yellow hoſe.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I have no voice to ſing, yet I will ſay
That this is Straw's and Touchſtone's bridal day.

sp.speaker: Goodw.
sp.l: Sure Hermes now is climbing to his height,
Who doth inſpire your wits to verſifie;
I would the Prieſt were come, for any time
This day will ſerve to do the trick you talk't on!

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: I, to get Wits, and I do mean to call
All my boyes Strawes, and all my wenches Touchſtones.

sp.speaker: Dove.
sp.l: Maſter, heaven give you joy, fame ſings that you
Are towards a wife, and I have brought a Prieſt •

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Your office bids you welcome, ſo are you.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I thank my office then, let him thank you.
But know Sir, that I am no Prieſt, but ſervant
Vnto a ſiſter of this Gentleman's;
She's now in town, and doth by me invite him
This day to dine with her at her own lo • ging.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: I prethee tell her ſhe ſhall dine with me;
She ſhall have gloves to boot, and you, and you▪
And now I think on't, ſhe and my couſin Win
Shall be my bride maids, prethee tell um ſo.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Firſt I muſt tell you, that I do not mean
To make a fruitleſſe errand; my adventure
Is to redeem you from theſe Harpies clawes.
Good Prethee how many Harpies are there here▪

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: E'ne a full meſs, of every ſex a pair.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Peace, or I'le teach your Gipſie-ſhip ſome manners.

sp.speaker: Dove.
sp.l: Would you would teach your ſelf ſome honeſty;
Vncloud your brow Sir, for 'tis not a frown
Can fright us from our purpoſe; therefore Sir,
Reſolve to leave this ſhop of ſin and ſhame,
This furniſht ware houſe of Iniquity.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Honeſt Tom Huntſman, have but patience.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.l: Is this a Huntſman Sir? now out upon him.
He ſmells moſt vilely of the kennel; ſuch a one
As this ſame fellow is, and ſixteen couple,
Did eat my father quite out of the countrey.

sp.speaker: Dov.
sp.l: 'Tis cheaper keeping a whole hoaſt of dogs,
Then one ſuch coſtly fizling hound as you.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Now out upon thee naughty man, prophane

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: driver, call heaven's creatures fizling hounds?

sp.speaker: Dov.
sp.p: And ſal • Bitch too, for ſuch are ſhe & thou.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: This idle rogue would fain be beaten ſure.

sp.speaker: Dov.
sp.p: I would indeed, 'tis one part of my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: You ſhall not go without your e • rand then.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser • .
sp.l: Hold friend • , as you are men, this open houſe
Promiſt the ending of ſome feaſt, but weo
Are come to the beginning of a fray.

sp.speaker: Dov.
sp.l: About your buſineſs friend, that is the man.

sp.speaker: 2. Serj.
sp.p: Sir, the King greets you well.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I'me glad he's well.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ye are two paltry knaves, thus to intrude
Into a private houſe; good Gentlemen,
Free a poor widows houſe from theſe vile catch-poles.

sp.speaker: Dove.
sp.l: Away Sir, we will free't from honeſt men.

sp.speaker: Good▪
sp.p: Vnhand me Sirs, I mean to put in bail.

sp.speaker: 1. Serj.
sp.p: Diſcharge the debt Sir, that's your only bail.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why what's the debt? here's one will ſee you paid;
Oh me! he's gon, but I will follow him.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I prethee Hog aſſiſt me 'gainſt theſe villains.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: Looſe him, or elſe by Termagaunt I will.

sp.speaker: 2. Serj
sp.l: Will ye be pork or bacon, I'le provide
A feaſt for Pluto; hence, unleſſe you mean
The Furies ſhall make Puddings of your guts.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Good friends do not abuſe the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 1 Serj.
sp.l: We'le not abuſe him chicken, for thy ſake
We'le ſee him where he ſhall be ſafe enough.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: Come Mrs. Lyddi, let us in, you ſee
It is not in our power for to help him.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Let your unmanner'd gripe unſeize my ſhoulder,
Or I will time your heads into a nooze,
As Hipponax did Bupalus, or buskin'd
Archilocus Lycambe, I will rogues.

sp.speaker: 2 Serj.
sp.l: That's a good jeſt I ſwear, I'de fain ſee that;
This fellow's ſure in a Poetick rage.

sp.speaker: Good
sp.l: Or if your fears make you decline the rope,
I'le brand your name with profound infamie.

sp.speaker: 1. Serj.
sp.l: Profound infamie? what a fine word's that;
Go D'ye grin ye dog? would I were looſe again.

sp.speaker: 2. Serj.
sp.l: No ſir, the dog's name's holdfaſt, that you'le finde.

sp.speaker: Cun
sp.l: Kickt, beaten, cheated of my gueſt? was ere
Poor woman thus abus'd; but which is worſe,
My ſilly Neece fondly reſtor'd the bag
Of which ſhe once was Lady Treaſurer.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: This is ill newes, my hopes lay in that bag;
Sweet Miſtreſs lend me for an hour or two
The ſeaſonable price of my releaſement,
You know my friend will faithfully repay't.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Alas good Sir, what would you have me do?
You know how poor and nakedly we live,
All I can lend's my pity and my prayers.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Thy pity proves me wretched, and thy prayers
Do make me hopeleſs, for they'l nere be heard.
Keep your devotion till your Carting, Madam,
And leave me to the mercy of theſe fiends.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Sweet man, I have no power to part from him.

sp.speaker: Goo.
sp.p: Then ſtay there ſtill, my kind affliction.

sp.speaker: 1. Serj.
sp.p: Come Sir, you ſee your hopes, pleaſe you walk?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Yes, lead me on unto my Purgatory;
Yet ſtay a while and hear a word of reaſon.

sp.speaker: 2. Serj.
sp.p: Let it be brief reaſon then, very brief.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: 'Tis only this, I know by circumſtance,
You are employ'd by draper Whittington.

sp.speaker: 1. Serj.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, if this be all, let's walk.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: The debt which you arreſt me for is owing
• or this ſame cloak I wear, the debt is young,
This the firſt day of wearing; give you him
His cloak again, and me my liberty.

sp.speaker: 2. Serj.
sp.l: He did give us no ſuch commiſſion ſir,
Yet what lyes in our power we will befriend you,
We'le place you where he ſhall be ſure to finde you;
That if his pleaſure be to viſit you,
You may your ſelf deliver the condition.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: If this be all your kindneſs, march away;
Farewell old noble true-penny, farewell.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Farewell ſweet man, I cannot chuſe but weep.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Now I am yours, yet ſtill my mind is free,
To triumph over Fortunes injury.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Believ't, 'twas no ſmall task to get him off.

sp.speaker: Eliſ.
sp.p: Where have you diſpos'd of him in love's name?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Where he muſt learn loves leſſon, with my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Eliſ.
sp.l: I hope that he will learn by her example:
But what's the reaſon Dove, you did warn me
Of my new ſuiter, whom you ſent, who does
With confidence uſurp my Friendly's name;
And why did you direct him to a Painter,
Who trimly made his mole on the wrong ſide?

sp.speaker: Dov.
sp.p: Only ſweet Miſtreſs, for to make you merry.

sp.speaker: Eliſ.
sp.l: Thou didſt not miſs thy ayme, for I did laugh
To ſee my fruitleſſe labours. When I could
By no mean • make him think he was not Friendly,
But when I call'd for water, for to prove
Whether he would endure the teſt; Lord how
The Gallant chaſ' • . But yet my Couſin Win
Thought all this while I did but counterfelt,
Untill ſhe ſaw a juſt diſdain poſſeſſ •
My brow. Then ſhe indeed began to blame
My unkind entertainment of a ſtranger.
To her I left him then to make amends,
For that wherein my rudeneſſe did offend;
And if I am not in loves art miſtaken.
(As ſure I am not) my ſweet Coze is taken.

sp.speaker: Dove.
sp.l: May heaven ſay amen unto your gueſs,
Then am I maſter of my ends▪ for he
I • rich and thrifty, and I yet may live
To ſee my Mrs. Win my Lady M • yoreſſe.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Faith I do long to ſee how much he's like me.

sp.speaker: Eliſ.
sp.l: Indeed 'tis pity ſor • o interrupt em.
Did you not ſay you knew my other ſu • er▪

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Hang him a ſlave, which rents his hackney chin
To city falling-ſtars, and toothleſſe madams.
But I will ſowee him for his ſ • welneſſe.

sp.speaker: Eliſ.
sp.l: He is more ſawcy yet then you doe think;
Now I receiv'd this Letter, pray you read it.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I am not ignorant how well you love me▪
And Lovers know what Lovers moſt deſire.
I hear your Vncle's not in town. I leav't
Vnto your wit for to beguile your Couſin,
And meet me ſoon a • Mrs. Cunnimongers.
Il'e read no more! mouſter of goatiſh boldneſs;
May he firſt twine with Scorpions. • or love's ſake
Tell me of what complexion are my hoſe?

sp.speaker: Eliſ
sp.l: •• me jealous of my ſelf, although not guilty
Of word or look, which cattled leſſe then ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Dove.
sp.l: Il'e ſolve this riddle. But this very morning
I met him here, enquir'd how well you liked
H •• Blac • a • ore. I did reply the truth,
And added this which I did think wa • true,
(And which no doubt' • the cauſe of his preſumption)
That you did love him better for his gift.

sp.speaker: Eliſ.
sp.l: You ſhould have ſaid that I did hate him leſſe.
But now I hate him moſt, who thinks me falſe.

sp.speaker: Dove.
sp.l: The carriage of this buſineſſe leave to me,
Il'e ſit him with another bed fellow,
Onely lend me your name to bring him on.

sp.speaker: Eliſ.
sp.l: Be ſure my honour do not ſuffer in't.

sp.speaker: Dove.
sp.l: 'Tis in your power to ſecure your honour.
What ſitter time then this to tie that knot,
Which onely fate is able to untie?
Let this hour execute the heavens decree,
And the Prieſt joyn their hands whoſe hearts agree.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: I dare not to diſſent from his advice,
Seeing time it ſelf doth ſeem to counſell us.

sp.speaker: Eliſ.
sp.l: Thy goodneſſe (Friendly) won me, let thy virtues
Guide me, for them I ever will obey.

sp.speaker: Dove
sp.p: he ſpeedy then, for time makes no delay.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: Hard hearted Tigre, unkind Adamant.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You are miſtaken ſir, my name is Phillis.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: O thou haſt kill'd me with thy cruelty.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Have dead men learn't to walk and talk again?
Truſt me, I nere ſaw ghoſt yet better ſed.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I live, but yet a dying life.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Leave your book-wooing ſir, you doe not doe
It handſomly, If you will love by art,
Your careleſs habit muſt proclaim your paſſion;
Your hat without a band, Garters unti'd,
Your trayling Cloke, dejected look, croſs armes,
Should be dumb arguments of your affection.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: If this be all, I'le quickly prove I love.
Hat be no more acquainted with a band,
Garters be never ti'd again, and thou
My careleſſe Cloke be witneſſe of my woe,
While thus I look, and thus I croſſe my armes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Next you ſhould ſing loves power, and your misfortune,
Which lord it o're you in a diſmal ditty.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l:
I'le ſing no ſong but this. Phillid •
flouts me:
Yet now I think on't, ſummer laſt, when firſt
I ſaw you. I compil'd this ſugred ſonnet

Phillid •
was a fair maid,
As freſh as any flower;
Whom Harpatus the Heardſman pr • y'd
Might be his Paramour.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But Philliday was all to coy
For Harpatus to win,
For Corin was her onely joy.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: Prethe ſweet heart, let me be Corin then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, I will not require your love with ſcorn.
Your love ha • h purchas'd mine, on this condition,
I muſt command your houſe. Welcome my friends,
Keep ſhocks, and monkeys, para • s, parakitot •• ,
And all things elſe I like for my delight.
Wear clothes befitting your eſtate, my birth,
You ſhall keep what retinue I think fit.
What horſes, coaches, litters; and what not▪
And when I pleaſe you muſt be lorded too.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: I will be any thing which thou wilt have me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You ſhall be nothing then, which not becomes you▪
I know lords not ſo rich, nor half ſo wiſe.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: Touchſtone farewel, thy Straw bids the • adieu.

sp.speaker: Dove ſings.
sp.l: Come, come away, to the Temple I ſay,
And celebrate this Wedding day.
Your ſiſter, maſter, and your brother, miſtreſs
This day are to be married, and expect
Your company to grace the Nuptials.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: To morrow I do mean they ſhall grace ours.
Tom, ſhe's mine own, my Wit at laſt hath won her.

sp.speaker: Dov.
sp.l: Make it one buſineſs then, let's haſt & get
A Licence, though 'tis late i'th' afternoon;
I have procur'd a Prieſt apochtyphal,
Who not regards the houres Canonical.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: A men ſay I.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: In troth ſo do not I.
Did you not ſay that you were dead? I will
Not dance the ſhaking of the winding-ſheet.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: I am reviv'd again, my pretty duck;
But I do wonder where my Falener is.

sp.speaker: Dov.
sp.l: I met him and his doxy marching now
With Mr. Conſtable, before a Juſtice;
When he's at leiſure, doubtleſs he'l find you out.
Mean while your own occaſions beg your haſt.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.p: Come then away, god Cupid be our ſpeed.

div.stage: Enter Iuſtice Budge, Falconer, Grace, Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.p: Sirra▪ how durſt you get this maid with child?

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: May't pleaſe you ſir, it is a native valour▪
Deriv'd upon me from my anceſtors.

sp.speaker: Budge.
sp.l: Well ſirra, well, I'le teach you not to have
The fear of grace before your eyes, I will.

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: That leſſon I have learnt already ſir;
And practis'd too, and to ſay truth, with us
We uſe to fall to without ſaying grace.

sp.speaker: Budge.
sp.l: The truth is, thou art an ungracious varlet;
'Tis well for thee my wife is not at home,
She'd ring thee a peal ſhould make thy eares to tingle;
Mr. Conſtable knowes ſhe can ſpeak well.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: For wit ſhe is the glorie of herſex,
And fame doth ſing her worthy to be wed
To one alone, who ſits in juſtice ſeat;
Her tongue is tipt with Eloquence, for this
And for her other gifts, the city rings on her.

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.l: And well it may, you know ſhe is a Bell,
That is, you know her name is I ſabell.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Now by my Ioan▪ a witty Apophthegm.

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.l: And fellow what ſaiſt thou? this 'tis to ſhed
My wit amongſt unletter'd Animals.

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: Blame rather ſir the height of your conceits,
Which are exalted far 'bove humane ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Conſt
sp.p: What doſt thou call his worſhip non-ſenſe?

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.l: Let that alone, and go we to the purpoſe;
Fellow, wilt have this woman to thy wife?

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: My name is Richard ſir, & I will have her,
With the ſame will I did appear before you.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.l: Well, if thou wilt not have her to thy bride,
I mean to have thee married to Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: 'Tis good again, incomparably good!
Fal Good do you call' til' me ſure tis bad for me.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.p: Woman, how doſt thou uſe to call thy name?

sp.speaker: Orac.
sp.l: My name is Grace, an it ſhall like your Worſhip.
Budg. It likes my worſhip well, but this vile fellow
Wants grace, and yet rejects it when tis offer'd.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: This is ſtill good, better and better ſtill;
Si • ra, how doſt thou like his Worſhip's wit?

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: I think his brain is like a lottery,
Where blanks and prizes moſt unequally
Are mixt; his common talk I call the blanks,
His jeſts the prizes, of which alſo are
Twenty of little worth, for one of value;
Of which firſt ſort when now there were drawn three,
Your tongue was trumpet to the lottery.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Sir, this is open Scandalum magnatum.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.l: See where my Clark and's Miſtris are come home.
That he may quickly write his Mittimu • .

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: Pray ſtay your Iourney friend, rather then ſo,
Il'e marry this ſame ſmall impediment.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.l: That might have ſerv'd your turn, but now you are
To be committed for a pettie Treaſon,

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.p: Will you your ſelf be judge in your own cauſe?

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.l: And who ſo ſit as I? for who will do
Sir Roger Budge more right then Iuſtice Budge?

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: Then here upon my knee I humbly beg,
That you'l be mercifull as you are wiſe.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.l: And I, that you'l be Iuſt as mercifull;
That is, that you will make him marry me.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.l: He has his pardon upon this condition.
Come riſe my friend, I'me pleas'd with thy ſubmiſſion:
And Grace I thus will grace in greeting her. kiſ.
This night you all ſhal ſup with me, where we'l ſet
Confirm the match, and I believe 'tis time,
For now me thinks my ſtomach 'gins to chime.

div.head: Act. V. Scaen. 1.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Shame and perdition fall upon this gipſie.
His falſe predictions are like oracles,
Deceiving with their Ambiguity.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: What alles the man? ſir, have unquiet dreams
Troubled your reſt to night, that you thus talk
Wildly of gypſies, and predictions;
Of oracles and ambiguities.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I'le tell thee Hog, I had a fortune lately
Told me, which did imply I ſhould Injoy
Her, unto whom I oft had ſu'd in vain,

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: Your Fortunes true for you have often ſu'd
Unto my Miſtris Lydia in vain.
Becauſe her nights were at too dear a rate,
Yet you have found her threwn into your arm's.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I do confes't, and therefore I complain
Upon my Fortunes ambiguity,
Which I applyed unto a wealthy heir,
Whoſe maiden zone I hop't for to untie.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: I hope that Lydia made you ſport enough,

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I'le not deny't, yet the miſtake doth vex me,
Though 'tis my Ioy I am not gull'd alone

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: If to Injoy fair Lydia alone,
You call a gull, then you are gull'd alone,

sp.speaker: Shift
sp.l: I mean this gipſie hath deceived others,
(If it be lawfull to believe a Huntſman)
For tolling this ſweet Ladies fortune, whom
But now I nam'd, before a Cityzen
Who did uſurp the name of her olde ſervant,
He ſaid within three nights ſhe ſhould Embrace
The man whom ſhe would honour with the ſtile
Of Husband, whom ſhe preſent did behold
Though his diſguiſe did then conceal his perſon,
Which the vain gull apply'd unto himſelf,
When I more juſtly may the Fortune claim,
Becauſe I am not what my outſide ſpeaks me.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: How can that be, ſeeing you were not preſent?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: She might behold me preſent to her fancy.
This meaning only my thoughts look't upon.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: For ſhame leave talking of theſe galleries,
The truth is this, the Huntſman whom you nam'd
Did purchaſe you the pleaſure of this night,
Remember now you told me in the Evening
When you were drunk with wine and Ioy, you meant
To Wed this beauty, which you came to meet,
But found contriv'd in bed before you came,
S • y then ſir, will you marry Lydia?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Thou know'ſt ſhe has a fooliſh property
Might make me pardon my ſelf this miſtake,
Yet I regard not that which nicer men
Do blame; the thing I might diſlike in her
Is, that ſhe's poor, but yet to ſhew, that I
Am a Philoſopher, I'le marry her.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: Nobly and wiſely ſpoke, and chear your heart
Though ſhe be poor, ſhe cannot make you poorer

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: This conſolation my Philoſophie
Doth likewiſe teach me, but I'le tell thee news,
I have a husband in the pickle too
For thy old Miſtris, one of her own trade,
For both of them do live by coupling ſexes,
He in olde Saxon's call'd a march-maker.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: Good ſir for once do you uſurp his office
To make this decent match, and I'le aſſiſt you.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I do arreſt thy promiſe, yeſterday
I hear his worſhip ſought me at my lodging,
But firſt I'le give him a preparative.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: I'le give him that ſhall work I warrant you;
Firſt I'le advance my Mrs. wealth and vertues,
Then ſweat the greatneſs of my own revenew's,
Which I gain only by the Fees of ſuiters.

sp.speaker: Shift
sp.l: I do not doubt thy art, go and prepare
Thy Mrs too, within this hour or two
I'le ſend him, untill then adieu.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.p: And why wilt thou needs have me marry thee?

sp.speaker: Grace
sp.p: 'Cauſe I would have you make me an honeſt woman.

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.p: Why doſt thou think all married women honeſt?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.l: I cannot tell, but ſurely I am one
If I am brought a-bed in matrimony.

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: Is that the point? but tell me when y'are married.
How think you to maintain your honeſty?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: You know the Iuſtice promis'd us laſt night
His worſhips licence to ſell ale i'th city.

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: Now you have hit it; was't ere heard that women
Maintain'd her honeſty by ſelling ale?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Surely I hear it is a thriving trade.

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: Surely but not to thrive in honeſty;
For if ſhe be not open as her tub,
My Hoſteſs takings will be very ſmall,
Although her lanted ale be nere ſo ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: I will do any thing which you will have me.

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: Then firſt I'le have you to releaſe our contract,
Then I will have thee travel into Ireland,
There thou mai'ſt make a nurſe, 'tis better far
Then live by'th muddy trade of ſelling ale,
And thank my bounty, which hath qualified
Thy Inabilities for this Imployment.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Did not you ſwear that you would marry me?

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: I have done better chick, far better, for
I've layn with thee, which I had rather do
Twice twenty times, then marry the but once.

sp.speaker: Gra
sp.l: Ay me, & ſhall my love be thus requited?
Yet know it is not in your power to leave me,
The Iuſtice now is witneſs of the contract,
Who I am ſure will ſee it executed.

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: Now thou haſt truly ſaid, what marriage is,
That is, an execution, well, then ſince
It will no better be, lets quickly ſet
All things in order, and be executed.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: As nimbly as you can good Richard, for
My time draws near, and I deſire to be
An honeſt woman e're I am deliver'd.

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: Lets find my Mr. firſt, I do not mean
To leave him and his ſervice to ſell ale,
Where I laſt left him, thence, they ſay the devil
Fetcht him away, and ſure he hath been there
For they look all as if they had been frighted,
And ſtill he may be there, for they do talk
As if they were poſſeſt, come, let us go,
And when my Maſter's found, appoint the day
When thoul't be married and I will obey.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Then this ſhall be the day, I'le be thy guide
To find thy Mr. and more gueſſe beſide.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: The haſt of your return, I fear hath made
You leave more weighty buſineſs unperformed

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Care of your good makes me forget my own,
Yet in one day, (for know my clients do
Obſerve my day) I have directed ten
To their preferment, two to reputed maids
Which I do rank alone in my black book,
Three unto widows of the ſecond head,
And five to maids of juſt maturity.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Detrick are not you allied. unto the famous headſman of your name.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Somewhat I am, but whats the cauſe you ask?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Becauſe by you there is contriv'd the loſs
Of many maiden heads.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: You'r merry ſir,
For know our trades do differ much, as much
As the extreams of torment and delight,
My office is not ſtaind with bloud, and thoſe
Who ſuffer by my means do live to thank me,
I beg no pardon for my fault, before
The maid's depriv'd of her virginity.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Yet you may ask forgiveneſs afterwards
Of thoſe who curſe your pains, and find the hell
Of marriage worſe then a decollation.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: You ſhall want cauſe I hope for to comeplain,
When you ſhall ſee your flying love return
To meet you, that you freely may enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Thanks unto both our pains, that I have done
Already, our cloſe kiſſes have been warm'd
With the ſoft flame of love, and I have ſeal'd
The match ſo ſure, that it doth need no witneſs.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Forget not him then that procured your bliſſe.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I am ſo full of joy, that you ſhall make
Your own conditions, and beſides I will
(Be you not wanting to your ſelf) in your
Own way require you with a wealthy widow.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: I am not yet ſo frozen, but my blood
Will heat without a fever, be then pleas'd
To give me a full knowledge of my hopes.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: She hath a ſervant, who was ſometimes mine,
And ſtill deſires to be ſo, for the love
I paid to his deſerts, which he requires
In promiſing his aid to win his Miſtris.
But you have happily prevented him,
And therefore no man fitter then your ſelf
T'enjoy the benefit was meant to me.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: I cannot but confeſs my ſelf moſt fit,
And therefore I'le aſſent unto your offer.

sp.speaker: Shi
sp.l: You ſhall take letters of my commendation
To my old ſervitour, his name is Hog,
One whom his Miſtris juſtly doth regard.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Let me alone for to commend my ſelf;
I'le onely take your letters for to purchaſe
My free admittance, then condemn my cunning
If my own courtſhip do not win the widow.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Well may you ſpeed, I'le preſently go write.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Though 'tis no need, I'le help you to indite.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: How ſtrangely fortune guides my deſtinies?
It is not yet five moons ſince I liv'd fice,
Yet in a forrain haven, now I breath
My native aire, but want my liberty,
Which method of my fate, yet lets me ſee
Some likeneſſe in this contrariety.
For Spain to me was but a wider priſon,
From whence there was no way unto my freedome,
But in a hazardous capativity,
Glad in a floting priſon to be in immur'd,
Since 'twas my ſafety to be ſo confin'd
Where I did fear more dangers, then I now
Do ſuffer, and ſo the bounteous heavens became
My School-Maſters while they my mind prepar'd
For future ſorrow, by foregoing its;
And taught me, that my later ſufferings
Are little bleſſings by compariſon:
But that which leſſens not my miſery
In this conſtraint, is the ſociety
Of a good old man my fellow priſoner,
The Rhe • orick of whoſe love, would needs perſwade
I have no cauſe of ſadneſs, and I think
I have the leſſe, becauſe I think he loves me,
And why I know not, but lo here he comes.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Come I muſt chide you, 'cauſe you'l be alone.

sp.l: I take this place to be a monaſtery,
And we are all monaſticks by our order.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: This is a fain'd deriſion of your fortune,
I ſee your thraldome makes you melancholy.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Sir, I have learn't that there is nothing free
But what is infinite. Captivity
Is the inheritance of all things finite;
Nor can we boaſt our liberty, though we
Are not reſtrained by ſtrong holds, when as
The neighbouring aire confines us, & each man
Is thraldom's perfect emblem, for in all
The ſoul is captive, and the bodi's thrall.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Well can I ſee, that this Philoſophy
Is not the argument of true content,
But conſtrained patience, which ſeeks reaſons why
We ought to ſuffer, what we cannot flye:
But give me now to know my pardon firſt
Being granted for my curioſity.
Did fate or choice acquaint you with this gallant,
Who now unworthily doth ſee you want?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: I cannot without thanks recount the love
Of that good man, with whom I travelled, he
Was the ſole guide and guardian of my youth,
I was his onely care, his pupill, ſon,
So he, ſo all call'd and accounted me,
And I were moſt ingrate did I deny
My ſelf his ſon, whoſe love made me his heir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: This anſwer's ſtrangely wide from what I askt.
Now I am ſhewing how this good old man
Being very ſick, and ready for to pay
The debt he owed to nature, call'd me to him
And councell'd me for Eng • and, to receive
Some moneys owing him, but above all
To find a father: fate only lent him leave
To name his dwelling, and that done, he dyed.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Still you ſeem forgetfull of my queſtion.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: I now was coming too't? when I had ſpent
Thoſe ſums, my forward'ſt creditours would pay,
Then I began to ſeek a father, where
My Father did direct me, there I found
You Mr. of the houſe, but this young gallant
(As I then learned) his Fathers onely ſon
Who late had purchaſt both the houſe and land,
I thinking then my Father was the ſeller
Meant with a ſweet revenge to pray upon
The buyers heir, and therefore I entice't
His folly to the City, but now I
Do juſtly ſuffer for my foul intents.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: However then you miſt him, you ſhall find
A Father in that houſe, half uncle to
This vain expenſive gallant, now your cozen.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: But how can you aſſure me in this truth.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: My ſelf is witneſs of the time, when you
Were firſt committed to the carefull truſt
Of him who ſince adopted you his ſon,
My old friend Curtiſe, to confirm your faith,
Know. I am priſoner for a debt is owing
Unto your uncle this young gallants Father,
Which I was ſurety for, his rigour made
Me obſtinate, but dying, he beſtowed
This debt upon your Father, who is willing
To grant my freedome at an eaſier rate,
And I of him to purchas't at a greater.

sp.speaker: Good
sp.l: Thanks unto heaven and you, who thus have lightned
My ſorrows by the knowledge of a Father,
I have debts owing, which would ſet me free,
That I may now go ſee him, for if I
Am ſon unto the Guardian of this heir,
He's now in town with his fair neece & daughter.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I can command the price of both our freedomes.
And be you rul'd by me, you ſhall enjoy
A greater happineſs then liberty,
By a new bonda e but a ſweeter,

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: If our thoughts agree, your promiſe crowns my wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: When we are free. I will unfold the riddle
Before your Father, therefore my firſt care
Shall be we may enjoy an open aire.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: Sir, for my good old maſters ſake, I will
Do what I can, but this our little fort

I •
ſo beſieg'd with ſuiters, that I fear
The Governneſs will be conſtrained to yield
By open force, if ſhe be not enſnared
By ſome ſtrange ſtratagem of Poetry.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: I care not this for all their ribaldry,
I never read of widow, won by ryming.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: This and another thing will do the feat
Infallibly, but you ſhall hear a coppy
Sent her this morning, which you will confeſſe
Is very dangerous, thus it begins,
Even as the heedleſs flye, ſeeking to taſte
The liquor glutinous, is taken faſt
Within the galli-pot, ſo wretched I
Am caught, alas! by my viſcoſity,
Labouring for life in love-lime, ſuch is my lot
For to be drown'd in Cupids galli-pot,
Then call me as I am, 'tis all I crave,
Sweet widow, thy intangled gally-ſlave,
Who prayes to heaven, that by the ſtars direction
We of two ſimples may make one confection.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: This raſcal talks like an Apothecary.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: He talks ſir as he is and 'tis more likely
He will be worth his words, though he do promiſe
Miracles in theſe verſes following.
I am no common ſuiter, thou ſhalt ſee
I can do wonders by my facultie;
My d • ugs thy you h and beauty ſh • ll reſſore,
Level thoſ • wrinckles, which age'gins to ſcore
Vpon thy furrowed brow, thy fading hue,
Ceruſs of aſſes milk and Mercury,
Lac Virginis, but pedling trifles be
To what I uſe; I give not by my art
Colour alone, but ſtrength to every part,
Which work when I have finiſh't in thee, then
I'le Idolize thy beauty with my pen.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: And when this Idoll's ſet up by the Noddy
I'le be the man ſhall worſhip her with my body.
You ſee ſir, I can time too for a need.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: Sir I am glad of your abilities.
Which may prevail, if that his threatning lines
Writ in poetick rage, do not o're come her,
When you have heard them with a judging ear,
You cannot blame her if ſhe love for fear:
Thus he goes on.
Yet know he begs who may command; my skill
Can temper for thy ſcorn a draught ſhall fill
Thy veins with rage, till thou haſt ſpent a night
In my Embrace, and dull'd it with delight,
I ove-ſalle's cropt by Circe and Medea
Which Sagana with bold Canidia
Gathered by moon-light in mount Eſquiline
Are but weak Philters, if compar'd with mine?
Then think upon my power, and yield thy heart
Rather toth' prayers of love, then ſtrength of art,
Your humble friend and ſervitour▪ Iohn Peſtle.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: This Peſtle ſhall ne're pound i'th widows mortar.
I care not for his ſorc'ry, he conjures beſt
Can raiſe an active ſpirit in her circle.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: 'Tis that his verſes threaten, had ſhe ſeen um
I know not what effect they might have taken.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Has ſhe not ſeen um then? nor ever ſhall;
Thus ought ſeditious lines, haretical,
And Magical doctrine to be aboliſht.

sp.speaker: Hog
sp.l: But for you friend, your ears ſhall feel. that they
Are guilty too, of hearing of this doctrine,

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Nay, prethee honeſty be not offended,
Here is a quarter Iacobin to buy
Thee cooling Iulips to allay thy choler.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: I am appeas'd, now liſten to the way
How to obtain my Mrs. firſt you muſt
Take no denyall, women often yield
Sooner to importunity then reaſon.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Like to the warlike Ram I will aſſail her
So fiercely, that ſhe ſhall not dare reſiſt.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: The very name of Ram is ominous,
May you prove none of thoſe whoſe tongues are ſtout
And threaten much before the onſet, when
They come to fight, their noſes fall a bleeding;
Now know my Mrs. chiefly in her match
Regards delight, promiſe enough of that;
'Tis the beſt widow lime, you apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: I warrant thee I'le pay her debt is due
By rev'rend Solons law, thats thrice a month.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: Wiſe Solon was a fool, I do perceive
You know not the commandements of love;
If you could do no more then Cybels Prieſts,
Talk like a Satyr, or you'l never win her,
Promiſe enough, but if your Impotence
Fall in performance, be it at your peril.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Thou art too young to teach me how to woo,
I have prevailing Canons of my own,
Prethee begin the way unto thy Mrs.

sp.speaker: Hog
sp.p: So you might prove a warlike Ram indeed.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: To her I mean, not into her, that is
Go thou before, and I will follow thee.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.p: My apprehenſion doth obey you ſir.

div.stage: Ent. old Good. Crab. Eliſa. Friendly. Phillis. W • ittington. young Good. Frema • . Dove.

sp.speaker: Old Good.
sp.l: Cozens, heaven ſend you joy of your own choice,
As much as Mr. Friendly and his ſiſter,
He hath deſerv'd my Neece by freeing of
My Nephew from the hands of bawds & villains,
And cover'd this with a new benefit
In giving him his fair and vertuous ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Thanks unto heaven and you, I do enjoy
My hopes, my ſiſter more then ſhe could wiſh.

sp.speaker: old Good
sp.l: Thank heaven alone, you know my brothers will
Did bind my care to hinder you, next I
Confirm my daughters choice, joy to you all
As much as I conceive for the return
Of my long abſent ſon, by thee no grief
Shall trouble the juſt gladneſs of this day
which is augmented by your liberty.
Kinde Mr Freeman, unto whom I owe
Next heavens bleſſing, that I ſee my ſon.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: And I do owe to him that I am free,
'Tis for that goodneſs I ſaw ſhine in him,
I pay to you what rigour can exact.

sp.speaker: Goodw.
sp.l: Good Sir when your bag's unſealed, we will divide
Were I extream to you I were ingrate.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I need no ſuch requital, I have wealth
Enough, I only beg to be all • 'd
To both your vertues, by the marriage
Of your beſt ſon unto my onely daughter,
Vris & modis, I will make her worth
Five thouſand pounds, this is my ſum to both.
young Good. Sir, let me beg your favour for to ſeal
Your bleſſing with this grant, mine eyes have ſeen,
While ſhe did daily viſit her old Father,
More excellence united in her breaſt
Then there is ſcatter'd in all woman kind,
I never ſaw her but me ſeem'd, an Angell
Did come to comfort us, in our conſtraint,
ſhe is all good, vertue it ſelf Incarnate.

sp.speaker: old Good.
sp.l: But how are you aſſur'd, that ſhe who is
The Mrs. of ſuch noble worth, doth love you?
yo Good Such ſweetneſs can't want mercy, and her face
Silently tells me, ſhe is full of grace.
A thouſand graces on her poliſht brow
The throne of love, do lead their ſtately meaſures
And lower millions dance in either eye,
Their active rounds, with nimble majeſty,
And if my love to her do not deceive me,
I ſaw love lighten from thoſe eyes on me.

sp.speaker: old Good.
sp.p: May your ſucceſs, prove your love doth not erre.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: My prom ſe ſhall ſecure him, for I know
Her love of him, ſhe thinks her only vertue.

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: Lordings and Ladies ſave you ſave you all
My good old Mr you are welcome firſt
Vnto the City, and I beg my pardon
For the late cheat I pratis'd on the Farmer,
Next, I invite you all unto my wedding.
Cr. Faith Richard as your manners gave me leave
To marry firſt, ſo they might wiſh me joy too.

sp.speaker: Falc.
sp.l: To explate my fault I wiſh you double
Ioy. Ioy and Ioy; that is, Ioy upon Ioy:
For I confeſs I heard it by your neighbours
And that my ſometimes Fellow Francis is
My good old Mrs. ſon, and my young Maſter.
For which I Ioy, and wiſh him alſo Ioy.

sp.speaker: Yo Good.
sp.p: I thank you Richard, but is this your Bride?

sp.speaker: Grace
sp.p: For want ſir of a better I am ſhe.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Peace my Incarnate frailty am not I
Thy head, then give me leave to ſpeak ſir this
Is ſhe, that frivolous thing I muſt call wife.

div.stage: Ent. Hog (in a ſtrange diſguiſe, a Torch in his hand) Shife, Lydia, Derrick, and Cunnimonger, (following hand in hand.)

sp.speaker: Elder. Good.
sp.p: But ſoft, what have we here, a mask!

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: Leaſt any here, who has been muſled up
In ignorance, and never yet did ſup
Of the Poetick Fountain, ſhould miſtake me,
Who ever thinks thus from the mark is wide all,
For I am he is gueſt at every bridall:
Welcome god Hymen, I am he doth lead
With my directing torch, the Bride to bed,
Where ſhe with trembling joy doth long to taſte
Thoſe cares from which ſhe hitherto did faſt

sp.speaker: Shift
sp.l: Now Mr. Hymen you are out, my Bride
Doth know the relliſh of the thing you wait on.

sp.speaker: Hog.
sp.l: I was not out till you did put me out,
But by my god-head • e begin again.
The news of joyning of more loving hands
(Ioy bleſſe the time) in matrimonial bands,
Hath fill'd the mouth of fame, and therefore hither
I bring theſe paires that with you altogether
I may be preſent, ſuffer thein to be here,
And they ſhall recompence with mirth your cheer.

sp.speaker: Old Good.
sp.l: God Hymen's welcome and the gueſts he brings.
You ſir, I am inform'd have been a ſuiter
Vnto my Neece, and that regard will claim
An invitation, my old neighbour Derrick
Hath as much right as your divinity
For to be preſent at theſe nuptial's.
For beſides him we know no other Hymen;
Then mix your ſelves with us, and let us all
Contend who ſhall exceed in mirth, and may
The Brides ſweet brows preſage a glorious day.

div.stage: Hymen waves over his couples to the other ſide with his Torch.

div.head: Hymen's EPILOGUE.
div.l: Joy and content to all that fill
The round, we beg not to our skill
A ſolemn clap, but onely hope
We have arrived at our ſcope,
That's your unfain'd delight, this we
Do ſtill account our chiefeſt Fee;
And that we wiſh to every gueſt
As great as at our bridall feast,
That the reflection of your mirth
May bread in us a ſecond birth
Do give your ſmiles a plaudite.
